title: Slightly soggier than expected 2023 - 24 wet season will buffer Hawaii from earlier onset of drought , wildfire season : Big Island Now
message:
If you think the most recent Hawai‘i wet season, from October 2023 through April, was somewhat soggier than expected, you didn’t have your head in the clouds.
A kona low that moved through the Hawaiian Islands in December 2023 helped to ease drought conditions throughout the islands.
The wet season ended up being Hawai‘i’s 10th driest in the past 30 years.
Hilo International Airport saw 58.63 inches of rain and its seventh driest wet season in the past 30 years.
Maps for the 2023-24 wet season are available online for the Big Island and Kaua‘i.
event_breakdown:
Events:
1. Kona low bringing rainfall to the Hawaiian islands in December 2023.
2. Hawaii's 10th driest wet season in the past 30 years.
3. Hilo International Airport's 7th driest wet season in the past 30 years.
4. Online maps are available for the 2023-24 wet season for the Big Island and Kaua’i.

title: B . C . wildfires : Plans underway for resident return to evacuated town of Fort Nelson – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
FORT NELSON, B.C.
– The mayor of the regional municipality that includes the evacuated community of Fort Nelson, B.C., says he’s optimistic crews have “a very good handle” on the wildfire burning outside town and plans are underway for residents to return.
The mayor of the regional municipality that includes the evacuated community of Fort Nelson, B.C., says he's optimistic that crews have "a very good handle" on the wildfire burning outside town and plans are underway for residents to return.
The wildfire service dashboard showed 112 active wildfires across B.C.
on Wednesday with nine classified as burning out of control, including the Parker Lake fire and another, larger blaze burning about 25 kilometres northwest of Fort Nelson.

title: 2024 Central Pacific Hurricane Season Outlook calls for 1 - 4 cyclones : Maui Now
message:
Hurricane Dora, a long-lived hurricane that reached Category 4, passes south of Hawaiʻi marking the first major hurricane in the central Pacific basin since 2020.
(Image credit: NOAA)The 2024 central Pacific hurricane season outlook from forecasters at NOAA’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center and NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center, calls for 1–4 tropical cyclones across the central Pacific Hurricane region.
The outlook also indicates a 30% chance of a near-normal season and 20% for an above-normal hurricane season across the central Pacific hurricane region.
The central Pacific hurricane region is located north of the equator between 140°W and the International Date Line.
The central Pacific hurricane season begins June 1 and runs through Nov. 30.

title: Iowa Weather : Tornadoes kill 1 , cause major damage in rural city of Greenfield south of Des Moines amid line of severe storms
message:
Iowa tornadoes kill 1, cause major damage in Greenfield, south of Des Moines, amid severe stormsADAMS COUNTY, Iowa -- Multiple tornadoes tracked across western Iowa on Tuesday afternoon, leading to at least one death and causing major damage to a small city as robust storms roar to life in the Midwest.
The storm-related death occurred in Adams County, Iowa - about 90 miles southwest of Des Moines - the county medical examiner Lisa Brown told CNN.
A funnel cloud was seen and a wind turbine toppled and caught fire in Iowa amid severe weather.
The Des Moines International Airport temporarily closed late Tuesday afternoon as dangerous storms headed into Des Moines, prompting tornado warnings.
Emergency management officials in Montgomery County, Iowa, confirmed "multiple tornadoes" occurred within the county Tuesday afternoon, and no injuries have been reported thus far.
event_breakdown: Iowa tornadoes, Adams County, Iowa, storm-related death, Greenfield, Iowa, Des Moines, Iowa

title: Florida utilities grapple with unpredictable storms
message:
Leaders of utility companies and associations representing municipal utilities and electric cooperatives made presentations to the Florida Public Service Commission as the six-month hurricane season gets ready to start June 1.
For example, while a storm might be projected as a Category 1 hurricane, utilities will prepare for a Category 2 or 3 storm.
Forecasters are predicting a busier-than-normal hurricane season this year, in part because of warm Atlantic Ocean water that fuels storms.
Read: Citizens Insurance eyes backup coverage in case of hurricanesThe state’s four private electric utilities — FPL, Tampa Electric, Duke Energy Florida and Florida Public Utilities Co. — typically are allowed to pass along costs for hurricane preparations and recovery to customers.
In bringing in crews, Melissa Seixas, state president of Duke Energy Florida, said utilities “are literally staging an army.

title: Outdoor burn ban in effect for North Port
message:
NORTH PORT, Fla. (WWSB) - Per City Ordinance 26-28, the City of North Port Fire Chief has determined that an Extraordinary Fire Hazard now exists due to extreme drought conditions and wildfire threat; therefore, an Outdoor Burning Ban is enacted within the City limits effective immediately.
Within the City of North Port, the KBDI Drought Index that measures moisture in the vegetation and duff is up to 610 on scale of 0-800, and the Fire Index for the Sarasota County area is High on the Fire Danger Index (FDI).
The burn ban specifically prohibits any type of outdoor fire, such as campfires, land clearing burning, and pile burns.
Outdoor cooking fires in approved gas or charcoal BBQ grills are permitted; however, extreme caution is urged with these devices as well.
During this time of extreme drought, officials caution all citizens to take precautions when parking cars in dry grass, carelessly tossing a lighted cigarette, or anything that could cause a spark or ignition source.
event_breakdown:
List the natural-disasters events:
1. Extreme drought condition
2. Wildfire threat
3. Outdoor burning ban

title: NOAA prognosticates a below - normal 2024 central Pacific hurricane season outlook | News , Sports , Jobs
message:
The Maui NewsKAHULUI–The 2024 central Pacific hurricane season outlook from forecasters at NOAA’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center and NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center, calls for one to four tropical cyclones across the central Pacific Hurricane region, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
The outlook also indicates a 30% chance of a near-normal season and 20% for an above-normal hurricane season across the central Pacific hurricane region.
The central Pacific hurricane region is located north of the equator between 140°W and the International Date Line.
The central Pacific hurricane season begins June 1 and runs through November 30.
“As we look towards our coming hurricane season, we must prepare with the real possibility in mind that a hurricane could impact our community,” said Chris Brenchley, director of NOAA’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center.

message:
Dozens of wildfires are burning across Canada in May 2024 and sending unhealthy smoke blowing into the northern U.S. again.
Smoke from wildfires in western Canada led to air quality warnings across parts of the northern U.S. on May 13, 2024.
In short, people will need to learn to live with wildfire smoke.
Chicago was under air quality alerts several times during the summer of 2023 as wildfire smoke blew in from Canada.
(Image credit: Scott Olson/Getty Images)A few key improvements would go a long way for practical decision making around wildfire smoke.

title: Be prepared for hurricane season  24 | University of Hawaiʻi System News
message:
Reading time: 2 minutesThe 2024 hurricane season begins on June 1, and forecasters with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s ( NOAA ) Central Pacific Hurricane Center said the Hawai​​ʻi region could see fewer than normal tropical cyclones.
The 2020 hurricane season was considered below average, yet Hurricane Douglas became the closest on record to pass by the island of Oʻahu.
“As we look towards our coming hurricane season, we must prepare with the real possibility in mind that a hurricane could impact our community,” said Chris Brenchley, director of NOAA ’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center.
UH community members are invited to participate in the UH hurricane season workshops that are held over the summer.
All members of the UH community are urged to sign up for UH Alert to receive emergency text alerts.

title: 6 transmission resiliency strategies to combat extreme weather events
message:
Extreme weather events are becoming more frequent, resulting in deepened damage to electric infrastructure and escalation of losses in lives and property.
In this era of intensifying disaster events, the need to bolster our transmission infrastructure has become more critical than ever.
Strategies for utilities to improve electric grid resiliencyIn response to the increasing severity and regularity of extreme weather events, electric utilities must urgently pivot toward a proactive stance, drawing lessons from these past disasters to bolster the resilience of the future transmission grid.
ConclusionAs natural disasters intensify in both frequency and severity, electric utilities and transmission companies must take proactive steps to improve transmission resiliency.
By implementing the strategies outlined, transmission infrastructure can be strengthened to ensure that it remains reliable in the face of the growing threat of natural disasters.

title: Tornado devastates Iowa town , killing multiple people as powerful storms rip through Midwest
message:
GREENFIELD, Iowa — Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.
Multiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa.
The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.
The storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country.
Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.
event_breakdown:

- A powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town on Tuesday, killing several people and injuring at least a dozen. 
- The storm also knocked down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa.
- The same storm system brought strong winds, large hail and tornadoes to parts of Oklahoma and Kansas on Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.
- On Tuesday, more severe weather and tornado warnings hit Wisconsin, including warnings for the state's capital city of Madison.

title: Satellites capture smoke pouring from hundreds of wildfires across North America ( photos )
message:

title: Hawaii officials stress preparedness despite below - normal central Pacific hurricane season outlook
message:
HONOLULU (AP) — This year’s hurricane season for waters around Hawaii will likely be “below normal” with one to four tropical cyclones across the central Pacific region, forecasters said Tuesday.
Last year, during strong El Nino conditions, four tropical cyclones entered into the central Pacific.
This year’s below-average prediction is due to a quick transition from El Nino to La Nina conditions, scientists with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said in announcing the 2024 central Pacific hurricane season outlook Tuesday.
The central Pacific hurricane season begins June 1 and runs through Nov. 30.
“It’s important to prepare for that threat this season and not wait for a season where we expect it to be more active,” said Christopher Brenchley, director of NOAA’s Central Pacific Hurricane Center.

title: Canton , Haywood Co . leaders look for flood assistance during Washington , D . C . trip
message:
Canton Mayor Zeb Smathers is in Washington, D,C.
He and Haywood County Commissioner Brandon Rogers are participating in the American Flood Coalition's local elected leaders’ summit on flooding and sea level rise.
Leaders from multiple states are building relationships to find solutions to flooding, much like Canton saw during the remnants of Tropical Storm Fred in August 2021.

One thing they found as a result of that disaster response is that they had a need for more freezer and cooler capacity.

title: Winter storm rainfall in united kingdom and Ireland  made 20 % heavier by climate change
message:
It found that autumn and winter storms over the UK and Ireland were becoming wetter due to human-caused global warming.
The study found human-induced climate change had led to the average rainfall on stormy days becoming around 20% heavier.
It said the kind of intense storm rainfall seen in 2023/2024 had become 10 times more likely.
If temperatures rose further to 2C of warming, storm rainfall and seasonal rain would increase, the researchers said.
A warmer atmosphere holds more water vapour, a key factor in climate change driving heavier rainfall.

title: Here how goats help reduce flood risk in Sacramento
message:
SACRAMENTO — Goats and sheep are commonly used to help reduce wildfire threats by clearing away dry brush, but another flock is being deployed to help fight flooding in Sacramento County.
"Last year, it was pretty high and it's just scary because the houses are nearby," said Anna Cardoso, whose parents live near a creek.
About 300 animals are currently clearing brush along Strawberry Creek near Calvine Road, and once they've finished there, they'll move up north to Arcade Creek.
"These goats are very professional to get the job done quickly and make sure that they don't leave anything behind."
Many people who live near the creek support this environmentally friendly way to clear the overgrown brush.
event_breakdown:
List of natural-disasters events reported:
* Flooding in Sacramento County, California
* High water levels in Strawberry Creek near Calvine Road
* Overgrown brush in Strawberry Creek and Arcade Creek
* 300 animals are deployed to clear brush from Strawberry Creek

title: Western wildfire camera network is now the largest of its kind
message:
Firefighters battling wildfires in the Pacific Northwest will now have the world’s largest public-facing system of wildfire cameras at their disposal.
One of the cameras at an OHAZ monitoring towerWith secure login credentials, firefighters can now observe fire behavior and weather in real time from wildfire cameras throughout the western United States, said Nick Maggio, assistant director of wildfire technology for the UO hazards lab.
The operating software also uses artificial intelligence to detect new wildfire ignitions and deliver alerts to firefighters and dispatch centers.
"Wildfire cameras provide fire managers with better situational awareness so they can send appropriate responses, which could reduce the acres burned," said Jacob Gear, regional fire prevention coordinator for the U.S. Forest Service.
Firefighters, emergency managers and other qualified personnel who wish to obtain camera control access in the Pacific Northwest can receive login credentials by emailing wildfirehelp@uoregon.edu.

title: Heavy equipment , snow shovels used to clean up hail piled knee - deep in Yuma
message:
Updated at 7:00 a.m. on Wednesday, May 22, 2024By Colleen Slevin/APResidents in Yuma were cleaning up Tuesday after hail the size of baseballs and golf balls pounded the community, with heavy construction equipment and snow shovels used to clear ice that piled up knee-deep the night before.
Monday night's storm in Yuma shattered vehicle windshields, pounded the siding off buildings and broke many windows.
lt also brought heavy rain to the city of about 3,500 people about 40 miles (64 kilometers) west of Nebraska.
The hail was still about a half-foot deep (18.3 centimeters deep) on Tuesday morning, said Curtis Glenn, a trustee at Yuma Methodist Church, which had flooding and hail damage.
Most of the hail reported in the area ranged from egg-sized to baseball and golf ball-sized stones.

message:

Monday night's storm in Yuma shattered vehicle windshields, pounded the siding off buildings and broke many windows.
It also brought heavy rain to the city of about 3,500 people about 40 miles (64 kilometers) west of Nebraska.
This after hail the size of baseballs with the strongest core of the supercell caused widespread damage in Yuma.

title: Cooler , wetter weather reduces wildfire activity in northeast B . C .
message:
Fire fuels remain ‘very susceptible to ignition,’ however, wildfire service warnsThe BC Wildfire Service says cooler, wetter conditions are allowing crews to make progress in their firefight in the province’s northeast where thousands of evacuees remain out of their homes for a second week.
The service says in an update on Tuesday that the more seasonable weather has reduced fire activity and is expected to persist throughout the week.
The BC Wildfire Service dashboard shows there are 113 active wildfires across the province, 19 of which are known or suspected to have been human-caused, with 11 blamed on lightning.
The Northern Rockies Regional Municipality, which includes Fort Nelson, said in an update on Tuesday that it was processing access permits for essential services.

But it's warning that despite the favourable conditions, much of the province remains "unseasonably dry" due to the ongoing drought.
The BC Wildfire Service dashboard shows there are 113 active wildfires across the province, 19 of which are known or suspected to have been human-caused, with 11 blamed on lightning.

title: 2024 Atlantic hurricane season is primed for storms with  rapid intensification
message:
Along with the anticipation of an extremely busy Atlantic hurricane season, AccuWeather meteorologists are greatly concerned that conditions over much of the basin could have a significant number of storms that undergo rapid intensification.
Rapid intensification is a term meteorologists use to define tropical storms and hurricanes that quickly gain strength.
When warm water is combined with low wind shear and abundant moisture, the ingredients for rapid intensification are in place.
Not every storm will undergo rapid intensification, but when the conditions are in place, the chances of its occurrence are much higher.
Formation near land and rapid intensification near land are the two standout situations that can cause quick changes to the forecasts and risks.

title: Officials stress preparedness despite below - normal central Pacific hurricane season outlook
message:
This year's hurricane season for waters around Hawaiʻi will likely be "below normal" with one to four tropical cyclones across the central Pacific region, forecasters said Tuesday.
Last year, during strong El Nino conditions, four tropical cyclones entered into the central Pacific.
This year's below-average prediction is due to a quick transition from El Nino to La Nina conditions, scientists with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said in announcing the 2024 central Pacific hurricane season outlook Tuesday.
The central Pacific hurricane season begins June 1 and runs through Nov. 30.
"It's important to prepare for that threat this season and not wait for a season where we expect it to be more active," said Christopher Brenchley, director of NOAA's Central Pacific Hurricane Center.

1. Hurricane season around Hawaiʻi is likely to be "below normal".

title: Smoke covered 70 % of California during bigges
message:
As much as 70% of California was covered by wildfire smoke during parts of 2020 and 2021, according to a study from the University of California, Davis.
The study measured lake responses to wildfire smoke in 2018, 2020 and 2021 — the three largest fire seasons on record in California.
The extent of wildfire in California has quintupled since the 1970s, the study notes.
Scientific instrumentation needs to be present in lakes when and where wildfire smoke occurs to measure effects.
“We need to reframe how we’re thinking about wildfire smoke — as a seasonal weather phenomenon and not just an ‘event’ that happens and goes away,” said Smits.

title: Head of FEMA tours deadly storm damage in Houston area as more residents get power back – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
At the height of the power outages, nearly 1 million people in the Houston area were without electricity.
The widespread destruction of last Thursday’s storms left at least eight dead and brought much of Houston to a standstill.
The deadly winds tore through a wide swath of Harris County, where Houston is located, causing damage and knocking out the power in both lower income and wealthier neighborhoods.
Harris County Commissioner Adrian Garcia said some underserved communities might feel left out “because they see lights in nicer-looking neighborhoods go up.
You’re not left behind.”Authorities had initially reported the deadly storms were being blamed for at least seven deaths.

title: Madison : Damaging winds cause largest power outage in nearly 50 years
message:
Madison: Damaging winds cause largest power outage in nearly 50 yearsMADISON Wis. (CBS 58) -- Hurricane-force winds swept across Madison Tuesday night, May 21, causing one of the largest power outages in nearly 50 years, officials say.
The strength of the storm left more than 42,000 residents without power in the Madison-area, according to Madison Gas and Electric.
"This was one of the largest outages in MG&E history," said Steve Schultz, a spokesman for MG&E.
It marks nearly 50 years since tens of thousands of residents were impacted by power outages.
Officials compared the magnitude of Tuesday's storm to the Great Ice Storm of 1976 that left more than 600,000 residents without power for days.
event_breakdown:
List of natural-disasters events:
1. Hurricane-force winds swept across Madison causing one of the largest power outages in nearly 50 years.
2. The Great Ice Storm of 1976 that left more than 600,000 residents without power for days.

title: Winter storm rainfall in united kingdom and Ireland  made 20 % heavier by climate change
message:
It found that autumn and winter storms over the UK and Ireland were becoming wetter due to human-caused global warming.
The study found human-induced climate change had led to the average rainfall on stormy days becoming around 20% heavier.
It said the kind of intense storm rainfall seen in 2023/2024 had become 10 times more likely.
If temperatures rose further to 2C of warming, storm rainfall and seasonal rain would increase, the researchers said.
A warmer atmosphere holds more water vapour, a key factor in climate change driving heavier rainfall.
event_breakdown:
Here is a summary of the natural-disasters events related to autumn and winter storms in the UK and Ireland mentioned in the text:

1. Autumn and winter storms in the UK are getting wetter, according to research.
2. Human-caused climate change has lead to 20% heavier average rainfall on stormy days.
3. Intense storms like seen in 2023/2024 have become 10 times more likely.
4. If temperatures rose further to 2C of warming, storm rainfall and seasonal rain would increase.
